I wanted to test out dividend stocks last year and was looking for something Canadian to avoid paying the foreign dividend tax. As a joke I bought HMAX because it yielded 14% at the time. I thought I was just going to lose all the money I invested due to the high yield, but with the dividends, I outperformed SPY last year.

The yield has gone down a bit down to 12.5% or so, but its still currently outperforming SPY YTD. With 16k invested I made more in interest than with 6 figures sitting in my HYSA at my bank.

Its holdings are purely banks like RBC, TD, etc. and its payout is monthly. Its still a relatively new stock being just over 3 years old, so there isn't much chart data to go off of and I most certainly wouldn't recommend it on a long term horizon (5+ years). But if you wanna allocate some of your port to dividends, its a decent pick from my 1 year experience of holding it.

HDIV is similar except it has a lower yield at 10% and it outperformed HMAX over the same 1 year time frame (30% vs 23% in HMAX). Also I should note that I hold it in my FHSA and not TFSA.

Early replies (first 3)

61862142
50 is too much, portfolio theory says around 20-30 before it's not worth it and I would lean towards the smaller number

61862144
>>61862099
In general it's better to bet on something broader than something more specific. As long as the sector grows you'll grow but a company can easily fail even if the product or the sector is wanted. When I was younger I invested in Nikola because I thought I would be hedging against Tesla. Turns out the company was a mess and people don't care that they're sucked dry by Elon. I still believe EVs will be more important for long haul and business use.

>>61862287
MPT claims you can only diversify away idiosyncratic (company specific) risk, and at some point you have so many different companies and exposure to so many different sectors that adding another company doesn't reduce risk by much if at all. I think markowitz or sharpe has a mathematical proof on it out there somewhere. Apparently they say that number is around 20-30
I say lean towards less because you have to take into consideration transaction costs and time and energy spent reorganizing your portfolio and tracking your positions as well. If you're just an average person and not a portfolio manager getting paid you're probably just fine with 12-15
